categories.title: Prioritise People
categories.description: Put the interests of people using or needing nursing and midwifery services first

categories.title: Practise Effectively
categories.description: Deliver evidence-based care that is person-centred, safe and compassionate

categories.title: Preserve Safety
categories.description: Hold the interests of people using or needing nursing and midwifery services above your own interests

categories.title: Promote Professionalism and Trust
categories.description: Uphold the reputation of your profession at all times

standards.title: Treat people as individuals and uphold their dignity
standards.description: Treat people with kindness, respect and compassion. You should treat people as individuals and uphold their dignity.
examples: Listening to what people are telling you about how they feel
Treating each person as an individual with their own needs and preferences
Respecting people's right to privacy
Maintaining dignity during personal care
Using appropriate language and tone of voice
practicalApplications: Always knock before entering a patient's room
Use the person's preferred name and pronouns
Explain procedures before carrying them out

standards.title: Listen to people and respond to their preferences and concerns
standards.description: Make sure that people's physical, social and psychological needs are recognised, assessed and responded to.
examples: Taking time to understand what matters most to each person
Asking about people's preferences for care and treatment
Responding appropriately to concerns and complaints
Involving people in decisions about their care
Recognising when people need additional support
practicalApplications: Ask open-ended questions about patient preferences
Document patient concerns in care plans
Adjust care based on individual needs

standards.title: Make sure that people's physical, social and psychological needs are recognised, assessed and responded to
standards.description: You must make sure that people's physical, social and psychological needs are recognised, assessed and responded to.
examples: Carrying out comprehensive assessments
Recognising signs of distress or discomfort
Referring to other professionals when needed
Supporting people's social connections
Addressing pain and other physical symptoms

standards.title: Always practice in line with the best available evidence
standards.description: You must always practise in line with the best available evidence.
examples: Using current clinical guidelines and protocols
Keeping up to date with research evidence
Applying evidence to individual patient care
Questioning practice when evidence suggests change
Participating in research and audit activities
practicalApplications: Read current journals and research papers

standards.title: Communicate clearly
standards.description: You must communicate clearly and effectively with people, their families and carers within your scope of practice.
examples: Using plain English when explaining procedures
Checking understanding with patients and families
Adapting communication style to individual needs
Providing written information when appropriate
Using interpreters when needed
practicalApplications: Use the teach-back method to confirm understanding
Provide information leaflets in appropriate languages
Use visual aids for complex procedures
Follow up verbal instructions in writing

standards.title: Keep clear and accurate records relevant to your practice
standards.description: You must keep clear, accurate and complete records relevant to your practice.
examples: Writing clear, factual entries in patient records
Recording care given and patient responses
Documenting any changes in condition
Using approved abbreviations only
Ensuring records are completed promptly
practicalApplications: Document patient involvement in care decisions
Ensure records are legible and dated

standards.title: Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
standards.description: You must recognise and work within the limits of your competence.
examples: Seeking help when unsure about a procedure
Declining tasks you're not trained to perform
Asking for supervision when learning new skills
Recognising when patients need specialist care
Continuing professional development to maintain competence

standards.title: Use all complaints as a form of feedback and an opportunity for reflection and learning
standards.description: You must use all complaints as a form of feedback and an opportunity for reflection and learning.
examples: Listening to complaints without being defensive
Investigating complaints thoroughly
Learning from complaints to improve practice
Supporting colleagues who receive complaints
Using complaints data to identify trends

standards.title: Uphold the reputation of your profession at all times
standards.description: You must uphold the reputation of your profession at all times.
examples: Behaving professionally at all times
Dressing appropriately for your role
Using social media responsibly
Maintaining confidentiality
Being honest and trustworthy
practicalApplications: Act as a positive role model

standards.title: Display a personal commitment to the standards of practice and behaviour set out in the Code
standards.description: You must display a personal commitment to the standards of practice and behaviour set out in the Code.
examples: Following all aspects of the professional code
Taking responsibility for your own actions
Supporting colleagues to maintain standards
Participating in professional development
Challenging poor practice when you see it
practicalApplications: Lead by example in all interactions

metadata.source: Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) - The Code
metadata.disclaimer: This is a representative sample of NMC standards for demonstration purposes. Always refer to the official NMC website for the complete and current standards.
